title: Approve Minutes of November 13, 2025 Recreation and Park Regular Meeting

banana: The Alameda Recreation and Park Commission met on November 13, 2025, to approve minutes from a previous meeting and discuss various program updates. Key discussions included a teen programs update, an update on the Leydecker Park playground replacement (estimated under **$300,000**), and a review of the 2026 Annual User Fee Schedule. The commission voted to approve the revised fee schedule, despite significant public comment regarding a **46% increase** in aquatic program rental rates, which some users stated would make programs unaffordable.
Residents may see **increased fees for aquatic programs**, with some users concerned about affordability, while the **Leydecker Park playground replacement** is moving forward under budget.

title: Minutes

banana: The City Council is holding a workshop to review proposed updates to the **Banner Policy**, including new policies for **Park Amenity Donations** (Memorial Benches and Picnic Tables) and **Park Storage Units**. The banner policy revisions include a reduced display time from 60 to 30 days and added locations. The memorial donation policy outlines costs for benches ($2,000-$2,150) and picnic tables ($2,250), with specific park location restrictions. The new storage unit policy establishes annual fees ($50-$150) based on size and requires prior approval for placement on park property.
Residents interested in donating memorial benches/tables or storing items in parks will see **updated procedures, costs, and location restrictions** for these amenities.

banana: The City Council will consider approving a new Municipal Maintenance Agreement (MMA) with the Texas Department of Transportation (TxDOT) on **December 11, 2025**. This updated agreement, which supersedes one from **1986**, clarifies maintenance responsibilities for State Highways within the City limits. While the core responsibilities remain largely the same (State for ROW, City for outside ROW), the new MMA formalizes evolved practices and addresses changes like annexations and highway conversions. Notably, all bike lanes, bikeways, and trails on State Highways are now explicitly defined as the City's responsibility, as are pedestrian and bike railings on non-controlled access State Highways. Several City departments, including Transportation, Resource Recovery, Parks, Watershed Protection, and Energy, have reviewed and concur with the agreement. There is **no current fiscal impact**, but future funding may be required for aging infrastructure and new mobility projects.

This agreement clarifies **who is responsible for maintaining State Highways** within the city, including bike lanes and pedestrian features, ensuring ongoing upkeep of these critical transportation corridors.

banana: ['The item is a proposed local law (Int. No. 214) aiming to amend the New York City administrative code.', 'The core purpose is to establish a private right of action for individuals unlawfully detained based on civil immigration detainers.', 'It specifically targets sections related to the Department of Correction (9-131), Police Department (14-154), and Department of Social Services (9-205) by removing previous prohibitions on private lawsuits.', 'Key changes include allowing individuals or their direct relatives to sue for unlawful detention, seeking damages (including punitive), and declaratory/injunctive relief.', 'The bill explicitly states that courts may award litigation costs to the prevailing party and that this right does not limit other common law or statutory causes of action.', 'Sponsors are Council Members Hanif, Krishnan, Rivera, Powers, Restler, and Avilés.', 'The effective date is 60 days after the law is enacted.', 'No specific fiscal impact statement for this particular bill was found in the provided documents, which is a notable absence for a complex item.']

Local Law Int. No. 214 proposes a significant amendment to the administrative code of the City of New York, creating a **private right of action** related to civil immigration detainers and cooperation with federal immigration authorities. This means that individuals who believe they have been unlawfully detained by city agencies, such as the Police Department (NYPD) or Department of Correction (DOC), based on civil immigration detainers, or their direct relatives, will be able to sue the city. The law specifically modifies existing administrative code sections (e.g., 9-131, 14-154, and 9-205) by removing language that previously prevented such private lawsuits. Successful actions could result in various forms of relief, including **damages (potentially punitive)**, as well as **declaratory and injunctive relief**, with courts authorized to award litigation costs to the prevailing party. The bill, sponsored by Council Members Hanif, Krishnan, Rivera, Powers, Restler, and Avilés, is set to take effect **60 days** after it becomes law. No specific fiscal impact statement for this bill was included in the provided agenda documents.

This law will **significantly empower** individuals and their families who believe they have been unlawfully detained by NYC agencies due to civil immigration detainers. It creates a direct legal avenue for **financial compensation and injunctive relief** against the city, increasing accountability for city agencies involved in immigration enforcement. The changes will become effective **60 days** after the law is enacted.

The Utilities Advisory Commission unanimously recommended reaffirmation.
This action will **continue to fund local decarbonization programs** and potentially offset electric operational costs, with no direct new costs to residents.

title: Annual Aquatics Performance Update by Team Sheeper, Inc. – 45 minutes – Staff Presentation

banana: The City of Palo Alto's Rinconada Pool, operated by Team Sheeper, Inc. since 2018, presented its **2025 Annual Aquatics Report** to the Parks and Recreation Commission. The contract with Team Sheeper, Inc. was extended for **five years** on October 21, 2024, now running until **December 31, 2029**, with annual reporting as a key requirement.

Despite a **notable decline in summer camp participation** (attributed to external economic factors), overall aquatic utilization remained strong due to **measurable increases in youth group swim lessons and family open recreation swim**. Key improvements included a **10% increase** in summer lap swim evening hours, a **50% longer swim lesson season**, and a **112% longer open swim/family recreation season**. The operator also introduced a water exercise program and provided **878 scholarship youth swim lessons**, maintaining user fees with **no increases for three years**.

For 2026, Team Sheeper, Inc. plans to introduce **year-round youth group swim lessons** for the first time, starting in January, and increase family open recreation opportunities. They will also offer **early-bird registration discounts** for youth camps to boost enrollment. Total facility income for January-October 2025 was **$1,263,073**, with a **1% revenue share of $12,631** to the City. The ability to expand services is linked to sustained investment in recruiting and training staff, with **146 lifeguards certified** in 2025 and total employees reaching **215**.

Comprehensive Emergency Action Procedures (EAPs) are in place for water-based, land-based, and environmental emergencies (fire, earthquake, chemical spill). Facility closure protocols are also detailed for biohazards, mechanical issues, hazardous weather, and air quality, with specific thresholds (e.g., **AQI 130 for activity cancellation, AQI 150 for full facility closure**).

Palo Alto residents will benefit from **expanded year-round youth swim lessons** and **longer open recreation swim seasons** at Rinconada Pool, offering more opportunities for aquatic activities. User fees are planned to remain stable, with new **early-bird discounts** for summer camps. The continued focus on staff training and comprehensive safety protocols ensures a **safe and well-managed environment** for all pool users.

title: COA-0153-2025 (6 N Bloodworth St)

banana: This item, COA-0153-2025, concerns a major renovation and two-story rear addition to the historic Theophilus Snow House at **6 N. Bloodworth Street** in the Oakwood Historic District. The project, led by owner Matthew Brown with architect Bozhena Etin, aims to restore the ca. 1840 house to its pre-1977 appearance, reversing non-historic alterations such as aluminum/Masonite siding, smaller windows, and dropped ceilings. The proposal includes removing existing rear additions and deck, and constructing a new **806.94 SF** two-story rear addition, which will increase the total built area by **5%** (to **3630 SF**) and built mass by **2%** (to **2372 SF**).

Key exterior changes involve restoring historic window openings and installing **29 new full-size 1-over-1 wooden windows** (costing **$47,021.58** for windows/doors, **$50,430.64** with tax), replacing roofing shingles with brown asphalt, adding an EPDM roof cricket for water management, and restoring a historic chimney top. A new **286.74 SF** two-story rear deck and stairs, built of unpainted treated pine with lattice screening, will provide apartment egress. The exterior paint scheme will feature a brownish-red body (Giant Sequoia), tan trim (Antler Brown), and dark brown sashes (Antler Brown). A detailed tree protection plan is in place for regulated trees on the property. The application was received on **October 25, 2025**, with a committee meeting scheduled for **December 11, 2025**.

Staff identified a concern regarding the "squat proportion" of some new "E" type windows in the addition, deeming them atypical for the district, and several material/design specifications are pending further detail.

Residents in the **Oakwood Historic District** will see a significant restoration and expansion of a historic property at **6 N. Bloodworth Street**. This project aims to enhance the historic character of the neighborhood by reversing non-historic alterations and adding new living space, potentially **increasing property values** in the area. The new two-story deck and stairs will provide improved egress for tenants, and the detailed tree protection plan ensures minimal impact on regulated trees, preserving the neighborhood's green infrastructure.

banana: This report details the financial status and project updates for San José's park and recreation infrastructure, covering Fiscal Year 2024-2025. The **Park Impact Ordinance (PIO)** and **Parkland Dedication Ordinance (PDO)**, authorized by the Mitigation Fee Act (Chapter 14.25) and Quimby Act (Chapter 19.38) respectively, collected **$4.9 million** in in-lieu fees, contributing to a Park Trust Fund ending balance of **$100.4 million**. These fees, along with other revenues, funded **$12.4 million** in expenditures for park improvements, with major collections in Council Districts 3 and 4. The report highlights **$77.4 million** in Construction and Conveyance Tax allocations, including **$51.2 million** for project-specific capital and **$8.6 million** for ongoing maintenance needs.

Significant grant funding was secured, including **$4.7 million** for all-inclusive playgrounds, **$6.6 million** for the Coyote Creek Trail (Mabury to Empire Street), and **$4.5 million** for the future Brickyard Park. The **Measure P Bond Projects Fund** has an ending balance of **$18.3 million**, with the **$22.7 million** Columbus Park Soccer Facility being the last major project, slated for a Winter 2026 start and Q4 2027 completion. The 2017 Coyote Creek Flood Recovery efforts show a projected total expense of **$28.7 million**, with the City's share increasing by **$7.1 million** to **$15.7 million** due to lower-than-expected FEMA/CalOES reimbursements. In FY24-25, the Capital Improvement Program completed 8 major and 133 minor projects, adding **12.66 acres** of new/improved parkland and **2 miles** of new trails.

Residents will see **continued improvements and expansion of local parks, trails, and community centers**, funded by developer fees and various grants. Projects like new all-inclusive playgrounds and additional miles of trails directly enhance recreational opportunities. However, the **doubled City share of flood recovery costs** means other municipal funds may be strained, potentially impacting other services or future park projects.

title: Consent Agenda
PP25-001 - Amendment to Various Sections of the Municipal Code for Compliance with State Law and to Streamline Regulations.

banana: The San José City Council is considering amendments to **Title 19 (Subdivisions)** and **Title 20 (Zoning Code)** of the Municipal Code, primarily to align with new state laws and streamline housing development regulations. This comprehensive update, identified as Planning File No. PP25-001, aims to facilitate housing production and improve permitting efficiency across the city.

*   **SB 9 Implementation:** Revisions to Senate Bill 9 standards for two-unit developments and urban lot splits in R-1 (Single-Family) zones include flexible driveway easements (4-7 feet or 12-15 feet, depending on street width), an increased maximum Floor Area Ratio (FAR) to **0.65** (from 0.45), and new lot coverage standards (e.g., **0.75** for 1,200-2,500 sq ft lots, **0.65** for 2,501-9,000 sq ft, **0.60** for >9,000 sq ft). Height limits for two-story units near rear property lines are adjusted to **25 feet** (from 20 feet) within **15 feet** (from 20 feet) of the line. The ordinance also extends SB 9-type ministerial approval to **R-2 (Two-Family) Zoning Districts** and allows such development on historic properties of lesser significance, subject to objective design standards.

*   **Small Lot Subdivisions (SB 684 & SB 1123):** Incorporates state laws for ministerial approval of up to **10 new lots and 10 housing units** in multi-family and single-family zones, with a minimum density of **19.8 dwelling units per acre** (if lower than 66% of maximum allowable). Minimum lot sizes are set at **1,200 sq ft** for single-family and **600 sq ft** for multi-family, with an average unit size cap of **1,750 sq ft**.

*   **Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs):** Updates align with SB 1211, allowing up to **8 detached ADUs** on existing multi-family properties (not exceeding existing units) and **2 detached ADUs** on new multi-family developments. It also streamlines ADU condominium conversions.
*   **Group Homes:** New definitions and regulations ensure group homes are treated as single-family dwellings for zoning purposes, consistent with the City's Housing Element.
*   **Heat Pumps:** Allows heat pumps to encroach up to **2 feet** into setback areas (maintaining a minimum **3-foot** side setback) in various zoning districts.
*   **Hydrogen Fuel Cell Stations:** Streamlines permitting for these stations (SB 1418) in commercial and industrial zones.
*   **Secondhand Stores:** Removes the Special Use Permit requirement for general secondhand stores in Downtown (AB 2632).
*   **Density Bonuses & Ministerial Approvals:** Chapters 20.190 and 20.195 are streamlined for readability and compliance with state laws.
*   **Special Use Permits:** Allows for amendments to existing Special Use Permits, reducing the need for new applications for minor project modifications.

This ordinance was recommended for approval by the Planning Commission with a 9-0-1 vote on November 19, 2025, and an Addendum to the prior Environmental Impact Reports (Planning File No. ER25-220) found no new significant environmental impacts. The ordinance is scheduled for City Council consideration on December 16, 2025, and will become effective **30 days** after its second reading.

These changes will significantly **increase housing options** by streamlining the approval process for Accessory Dwelling Units (ADUs), duplexes, and small-scale multi-unit developments in many neighborhoods, potentially contributing to a more diverse and affordable housing supply. Residents will also benefit from **faster permitting** for home improvements like heat pump installations and clearer rules for development on historic properties. New construction projects will operate under standardized hours (7 AM - 7 PM Mon-Fri near residential) and include environmental awareness training, aiming to **reduce neighborhood disruption**.

title: Consent Agenda
Amendment to City Council Policy 9-5, Travel by Elected and Appointed City Officials.

banana: The City Council is considering an amendment to Policy 9-5, which governs travel by elected and appointed city officials. Report on the Request for Proposal for the Fire Department’s Background Investigations Consultant Services.

banana: The City Council will consider a report and resolution to authorize the City Manager to negotiate and execute an agreement with **DR Associates International** for Fire Department background investigations. This action ensures the Fire Department can continue to conduct thorough background checks on potential hires, maintaining **public safety standards** for those in critical roles.

Both fee programs are intended to fund affordable housing developments and are compliant with the California Mitigation Fee Act. The report indicates that no new disbursements or expenditures were made from either fund in FY 2024-2025, but committed funds for projects like Parkmoor Community Apartments are being tracked.
Residents are impacted by the **ongoing collection and reporting of fees** intended to fund affordable housing, though no new projects were funded by these specific fees in the reported fiscal year.

title: Consent Agenda
Report on Bids and Award of Contract for the 10594 - 2026 Local Streets ADA Curb Ramps #2 Project.

banana: The City Council is considering awarding a contract to **Spencon Construction, Inc.** for the **10594 – 2026 Local Streets ADA Curb Ramps #2 Project** at a cost of **$1,224,200**, plus a **10% contingency of $122,420**. This project involves upgrading and constructing ADA-compliant wheelchair ramps at various locations citywide to prepare for the 2026 Local Streets Pavement Maintenance Program. The work is scheduled to begin in **March 2026** and be substantially completed by **June 2026**. The funding for this project comes from the VTA Measure B Pavement Maintenance Fund.
Residents will benefit from improved **accessibility and safety** at street corners due to the installation of new ADA-compliant curb ramps across the city.

title: Consent Agenda
Amendment to Title 16 (Gaming Control) of the San José Municipal Code.

banana: This ordinance amends Title 16 (Gaming Control) of the San José Municipal Code to streamline regulations for cardrooms. Key changes include revising crime reporting timelines, expanding allowable betting squares on card tables from 10 to 20, repealing the 20-hour continuous presence limit for patrons, removing the four-tournament-per-year limit while retaining the 25% charitable contribution requirement (with an exception for lump-sum contributions), and explicitly allowing complimentary or discounted non-alcoholic food and beverages for patrons under specific conditions. These changes aim to align local regulations with current operational practices and state law, while maintaining public safety and regulatory integrity. The amendments are part of a broader effort to adjust staffing and fees for the Division of Gaming Control.

These changes will **streamline regulations for cardrooms**, potentially affecting reporting of crimes and allowing for more flexible tournament play and complimentary food/beverages for patrons, while also adjusting betting limits.

title: Public Safety
Shared Micro-Mobility Device Fee Adjustment.

banana: The City Council is considering a resolution to decrease the annual permit and monitoring fee for shared micro-mobility devices (like e-scooters) from **$139 per device to $100 per device**. This adjustment, effective **January 1, 2026**, aims to make the program more competitive and attract new operators, as the city received no applications in its recent solicitation. The current fee is considered a barrier to entry, being one of the highest in the western United States. This change is expected to allow for a new operator with approximately 1,000 devices, generating an estimated **$100,000 in revenue**.
This change will **reduce the per-device fee for micro-mobility operators**, potentially making shared scooter services more available and affordable for residents.

title: Consent Agenda
Fire Department Inventory Controls Over Controlled Substances Audit Report.

banana: An audit report on the San José Fire Department's inventory controls for controlled substances (morphine and midazolam) found no evidence of theft or tampering during summer 2025. However, the audit identified areas for improvement in policy clarity and the separation of duties related to managing these substances. Recommendations include revising policies to reflect current practices, formalizing procedures for monitoring and storage, and separating the duties of the Controlled Substances Program Manager to enhance security. The department has already implemented some interim controls and is working on policy updates and acquiring biometric safes.
This audit ensures **proper security and accountability** for medications used by the Fire Department in emergency medical services, ultimately protecting public safety.

title: Strategic Support
Digital Empowerment and Broadband Strategy.

banana: The City of San José is renewing its **Digital Empowerment and Broadband Strategy** to close the digital divide, aiming for **universal availability of 1 Gigabit/500 Mbps broadband by 2030** and universal choice between two or more providers. Currently, **12% of households remain unconnected or under-connected**, and the Digital Inclusion Fund faces a **50% revenue deficit** (projected **$10 million** over 10 years instead of $20 million). The strategy focuses on public-private partnerships, increasing digital skills training through **Tech Hubs** (6 currently supporting over **5,600 visits** annually), and upgrading City network infrastructure with **$6.9 million** for copper-to-fiber and **$26 million** for smart streetlight controllers. The City Council will formally adopt the FCC's **100/20 Mbps** broadband speed definition and the aspirational **1 Gbps/500 Mbps** goal.

This strategy aims to provide **more affordable and faster internet options** for all residents, especially low-income households, and offers **free digital skills training and device access** through community Tech Hubs and libraries.

title: Neighborhood Services
Abandoned Shopping Cart Retrieval Pilot Program Status Report.

banana: This report details the status of the abandoned shopping cart retrieval pilot program, which ran from August to November 2025. The pilot, conducted by contractor carTrac in two areas, collected a total of **734 carts**. Recent changes to state law (Senate Bill 753) now allow for cost recovery from retailers for cart retrieval. The city plans to issue a Request for Proposal (RFP) to establish an ongoing program, aiming for implementation by **early Fiscal Year 2026-2027**, with potential start-up costs to be considered in the **2026-2027 Budget process**.
This initiative aims to reduce the number of abandoned shopping carts, potentially leading to **cleaner streets and neighborhoods**.

Businesses within the district will be assessed a flat rate of **$350** annually, with a reduced rate of **$100** for qualifying entities. The estimated annual income, based on a 70% collection rate, is **$258,930**.
Businesses within The Alameda district will be subject to a new annual assessment of **$350** (or **$100** for qualifying businesses) to fund district-wide promotional and support activities.

title: Community & Economic Development

banana: The San José Mineta International Airport is seeking to approve the selection of Bank of America as the top-ranked proposer for Automated Teller Machine (ATM) concessions. This agreement is projected to generate approximately **$349,000** in revenue for the Airport over the initial term, and an estimated additional **$386,000** if all extension options are exercised, totaling approximately **$735,000** over the full period. Bank of America will provide four ATMs in high-traffic areas, supporting multiple languages and transaction types.
Travelers at the San José Mineta International Airport will continue to have access to **ATM services** with extended language support, with the Airport generating revenue from the concession fees.

The original agreement was for up to **$4 million** in incentives, and as of November 13, 2025, $4.40 million has been disbursed for 265 Level 2 and 70 fast chargers, with five projects totaling $2.23 million in reserved funds still in process.
This extension will allow for the **completion of more electric vehicle charger installations** across the city, supporting the transition to cleaner transportation.

This purchase is part of the Airport's initiative to replace aging compressed natural gas buses with sustainable electric alternatives, aiming to save approximately **31,200 gallons** of compressed natural gas annually. The purchase will be primarily funded by a **$1.8 million Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Zero Emissions Vehicle (ZEV) Grant**, with the remainder funded by the Airport Renewal and Replacement Fund.
Travelers using the San José Mineta International Airport will benefit from **newer, more environmentally friendly shuttle buses** connecting terminals, rental car facilities, and parking lots.

Fourth Amendment to the Agreement with Granicus, LLC for an Electronic Filing System for Form 700 and Campaign Finance Forms.

banana: The City Council is considering a Fourth Amendment to the agreement with Granicus, LLC for an electronic filing system used for Form 700 and campaign finance forms. This extension is necessary to allow sufficient time for the implementation and transition to a new vendor's system, which was awarded in September 2025, ensuring uninterrupted service.

This action ensures the continued availability of the **electronic filing system for Form 700 and campaign finance forms** during the transition to a new system, with a maximum cost of **$62,754** for the extension period.

Report on the Request for Proposals for an Emergency Management AI-Integration Data Modeling Solution.

banana: The City Council is considering a report on a Request for Proposals (RFP) for an Emergency Management AI-Integration Data Modeling Solution. This solution aims to enhance the City's ability to quickly process data for evacuation planning and response, building on a successful pilot program.
This initiative will **enhance the city's ability to plan and respond to emergencies**, potentially leading to faster and more effective evacuations and improved public safety during crises.

title: Consent Agenda
Actions Related to the Reallocation of Acquisition Funding to the Construction-Permanent Loan for the Gateway Tower Affordable Housing Development.

banana: The City Council is considering a resolution to reallocate **$18,170,000** in acquisition funding to the construction-permanent loan for the Gateway Tower Affordable Housing Development. Actions Related to Grant Agreements for Multiple Programs Serving Households Experiencing Homelessness for Fiscal Year 2025-2026.

banana: The City Council is considering authorizing the Housing Director to negotiate and execute amendments to existing grant agreements, totaling **$7,935,239**, for programs serving individuals and families experiencing homelessness for Fiscal Year 2025-2026. title: Consent Agenda
Amendment to the City Pay Plan.

banana: The City Council is set to approve an amendment to the City Pay Plan, effective December 21, 2025. This action creates new high-level administrative positions within the City Manager's Office, **affecting city government operations and management structure** but not directly impacting resident services or taxes.

title: Consent Agenda
Actions Related to the 2025 California Governor’s Office of Emergency Services Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force Grant.

banana: The City Council is considering a resolution to authorize the City Manager to apply for and accept the **2025 California Governor’s Office of Emergency Services Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force Grant** of **$1,350,000**. This grant, running from January 1, 2026, to December 31, 2026, will fund the Police Department's efforts to investigate and prosecute child predators. Funds will cover personnel costs for two Digital Forensic Analyst positions (**$415,284**) and operating costs including forensic tools, training, equipment, supplies, and software licenses (**$934,716**). The department has a history of receiving similar grants since 2003.
This action allows the city to seek grant funding to **combat online child exploitation and prosecute offenders**, enhancing public safety.

title: Consent Agenda
2024-2025 Annual Development In-Lieu Fee Report.

The **Utility Undergrounding Fee** was adjusted to **$622** per linear foot frontage in January 2025 due to a slight decrease in construction costs.

This report ensures accountability for development fees collected by the city, which are intended to fund public improvements like utility undergrounding and street enhancements, ultimately impacting the quality and infrastructure of neighborhoods.

title: Consent Agenda
Second Amendment to the Consultant Agreement with HNTB Corporation for the US 101 / Mabury - Berryessa - Oakland Corridor Improvement Project.

banana: The City Council is considering a second amendment to the consultant agreement with HNTB Corporation for the US 101 / Mabury - Berryessa - Oakland Corridor Improvement Project. This amendment seeks to increase the not-to-exceed amount by **$1,800,000**, from $9,000,000 to $10,800,000, and extend the agreement term to **December 31, 2028**. The project aims to improve freeway access, local circulation, and multimodal connectivity in the Mabury, Berryessa, and Oakland Road corridors, supporting planned growth and addressing existing congestion and safety concerns.

This action will extend the timeline and increase funding for a project that aims to **improve traffic flow and safety** along US 101 in the Mabury, Berryessa, and Oakland Road areas, with potential benefits for commuters and residents.

title: Consent Agenda
Resolution Establishing Speed Limits.

banana: The City Council is set to repeal Resolution No. **2025-304** and adopt a new resolution to adjust speed limits across San José, effective **December 16, 2025**. This action will **lower speed limits on 19 roadways**, including portions of Barack Obama Boulevard, Blossom Hill Road, and 10th Street (e.g., 10th St from 30 mph to **25 mph**), and **maintain current speed limits on 5 roadways**, such as Alum Rock Avenue. This review ensures that elected and appointed officials adhere to ethical standards, promoting **transparency and accountability** in local government operations.

Residents can review the official record of the Human Relations Commission's activities, which shape recommendations on **equity, access, and inclusion** initiatives within the city.
